Remarks

Each Position instance is generated by broker Pay attention that all properties of position are read-only and cannot be changed in instance after its creation. In other words, position is immutable and, consequently is thread-safe That's why Position has no any change events. Once you get the reference to the position object, you can be sure that all its properties won't change It means that each time a position is changing a broker adapter creates a new instance, so each position changed event is accompanied by new instance Also, each position list request may generate new instances of positions (depending on broker adapter implementation). So, never compare positions by object references. Use Instrument or OrderId instead

Pay attention that constructors of position are hidden and the class is abstract. It is impossible to create position outside. The position can be created by broker only And each broker must create its own derived classes to be able to create position instances

Properties

AlgoKey

Contains a key that can be used by a strategy to distinguish its positions from other positions Usually, the first order that creates a position sets this key

public string? AlgoKey { get; }

Property Value

string

AveragePrice

Average price of position. For hedging position it means open price. for netting positions - the average price of all openings

public double AveragePrice { get; }

Property Value

double

BrokerageProvider

Parent brokerage provider

public IBrokerageProvider BrokerageProvider { get; }

Property Value

IBrokerageProvider

CreateTime

Time of the creation of position Since not all brokers support this info, the parameter can be uninitialized (equal to MinValue) See also BrokerageCapability.PositionCreateTime

public DateTime CreateTime { get; }

Property Value

DateTime

Description

Any text information attached to position and stored on client side DB using ITradingEntitiesService

public string? Description { get; }

Property Value

string

Instrument

Instrument of the position

public Instrument Instrument { get; }

Property Value

Instrument

MarketPosition

Returns Long, Short or Flat depending on SignedQuantity If quantity is negative, then the position is short If quantity is positive, then the position is long If quantity is zero, then the position is flat

public MarketPosition MarketPosition { get; }

Property Value

MarketPosition

PositionId

Identification of position. Commonly is used for hedging accounts, where multiple open positions for the same instrument are possible. In this case Id is used to distinguish one position from another For netting accounts usually id = null because it may be identified by natural key: instrument

public string? PositionId { get; }

Property Value

string

Remarks

To stress out, that this id is broker specific, we use PositionId instead of Id (because Id is too general name)

Quantity

Position absolute quantity. To determine the direction of position use

public Quantity Quantity { get; }

Property Value

Quantity

SignedQuantity

Position quantity. Positive value means Long position, negative value - short position

public SignedQuantity SignedQuantity { get; }

Property Value

SignedQuantity

StopLoss

The stop order (also known as stop loss) attached to position

Current market prices. Each price (bid, ask or last) may be NaN if no appropriate quotes were received so far

MarketData

GetMarketPrice()

Returns market price to calculate current profit of position. For long position it is bid price, for short position it is ask price For flat position always returns NaN Can return NaN if there is no current market data (GetCurrentMarketData())

public double GetMarketPrice()

Returns

double

GetMarketPrice(MarketData)

Returns market price to calculate current profit of position. For long position it is bid price, for short position it is ask price For flat position always returns NaN Can return NaN if no price in marketData

public double GetMarketPrice(MarketData marketData)

GetUnrealizedProfit(ProfitCalculationUnit, double)

Returns profit in specified units If position is flat (quantity =0), returns 0 You also can pass your own market data price using price

public virtual double GetUnrealizedProfit(ProfitCalculationUnit unit = ProfitCalculationUnit.AccountCurrency, double price = NaN)

Parameters

unit ProfitCalculationUnit
price double

Returns

double

Returns NaN if current market data (current prices) is not available to calculate unrealized profit Returns 0 if the current position is flat
